original_title: Sri Lanka’s Lanka Special Steels boosts GI capacity
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Lanka Special Steels said it had opened a new factory with a capacity of 30,000 metric tonnes a year, which can cater to domestic and international markets, officials said.

The factory is coming on stream as the country’s construction sector is facing a downturn after the central bank printed money mistarget rates for monetary stimulus and triggered the worst currency crisis in its history.

“This plant has a capacity of 30,000 metric tons which will cater to all the needs of Sri Lanka’s galvanized wire and also gives us room to export,” Chairman of Lanka Special Steels, S D R. Arudpragasam told reporters
“Another factor in this plant is that we can run it at between 15 to 20 percent capacity.”
Lanka Special Steels is part of Sri Lanka’s EB Creasy group. It produces a range of galvanized iron (GI) products.

“The construction industry is also going through a tough time due to the liquidity issue in the market but construction is very much needed in the country to develop the infrastructure,” CEO of Lanka Special Steels Pravin De Silva told EconomyNext
“So, it will pick up, the moment the cash flow improves. With the IMF assistance the market will slowly progress.”
Lanka Special Steel already exports products to USA, Canada, India, Japan, South Africa and Middle East.
Lanka Special Steels Limited was earlier owned by TATA Steel and was acquired by the EB Creasy group. (Colombo/June14/2023)
